sections.list: Define project risk and identify various types of risks that may occur in a project.

sections.title: What is a Project Risk?
sections.list: An unpredictable event or situation that, if it happens, can positively or negatively impact the goals of a project.; Project risks can have positive outcomes, referred to as opportunities, or they can result in negative or unfavorable consequences, known as threats.

sections.title: Types of Risks
sections.body: Risks may be classified into two:
sections.body1: Internal Risk: Internal risks are those that may come from the organization. Project analysts must identify and prioritize these types of risks
sections.body2: External Risk: External risks are beyond the control of the project team and the organization hosting the project. These risks are typically harder to foresee and manage

sections.title: Internal Risk
sections.body: These risks occur due to strengths and weaknesses internal to the organization.
sections.body1: Schedule Risk are risk that activities may take longer than anticipated. Schedule delays usually lead to increased costs and postpone the realization of project benefits, potentially resulting in a loss of competitive advantage
sections.body2: Resource Risk are risks from outsourcing and personnel-related issues. Large projects may involve dozens or even hundreds of employees, making it crucial to manage attrition. Introducing a new resource at a later stage in the project can significantly slow down progress
sections.body3: Budget risks involve the escalation of project costs due to inaccurate cost estimations and scope creep.
sections.body4: Performance Risk are the risk that a completed project may not perform as intended or fail to meet the business requirements that justified its initiation
sections.body5: Scope risks encompass changes in scope, often resulting from scope creep.
sections.body6: Quality risks may arise if the product or project lacks clear acceptance criteria or fails to meet customer needs.
sections.body7: Technical Risk are potential technology failures that could disrupt business operations, such as information security incidents or service outages. Projects utilizing new technology may encounter the risk of the technology not meeting expectations. For instance, an e-commerce platform crash could lead to lost revenue. Operational risks also encompass issues arising from poor implementation and process problems, including procurement, production, or distribution challenges.

sections.title: External Risks
sections.body: These risks occur due to strengths and weaknesses internal to the organization.
sections.body1: Strategic Risk are risks associated with failed business decisions or indecision that may impact a company. These risks can lead to potential losses from pursuing an unsuccessful business plan. For example, selecting a technology for a project that ultimately cannot be made to work.
sections.body2: This risk arises from the potential for business activities to alter the status quo due to specific events. Examples include delays in obtaining legislative approvals from authorized agencies, projects located in coastal zones, negative community impacts, and natural disasters such as earthquakes, hurricanes, or volcanic eruptions.
sections.body3: Market risks are the potential for an organization to incur losses due to factors that impact the overall performance of financial markets.
sections.body4: Legal Risk are potential losses stemming from the unpredictability of legal proceedings, such as bankruptcy or impending litigation.

sections.title: Other Type of Risks
sections.body: Project managers must comprehend cybersecurity risks to safeguard their projects from cyberattacks. Below are some key cybersecurity risks to be mindful of.
sections.body1: Data breaches are among the most prevalent cybersecurity threats. In 2022, over 6.5 billion data records were exposed due to data breaches.
sections.body2: Phishing continues to be a significant threat in the banking industry. Cybercriminals use deceptive emails, text messages, or websites that appear legitimate to trick customers or employees into disclosing sensitive information such as account numbers, passwords, or personal details. Once they obtain this information, hackers can steal money, commit identity theft, or infiltrate the bank's internal systems.
sections.body3: Insider threats, whether from disgruntled employees, contractors, or third-party vendors, pose a significant risk to a bank's cybersecurity. Insiders with access to sensitive data can either intentionally or unintentionally leak information or create an entry point for hackers
sections.body4: These involve flooding a bank's online services with excessive traffic, leading to system slowdowns or crashes. This renders services such as online banking and payment processing unavailable. These attacks can be especially harmful to banks, disrupting business operations, frustrating customers, and leaving systems vulnerable to additional exploitation.
sections.body5: APTs are highly sophisticated attacks in which cybercriminals gain unauthorized access to a bank's network and meticulously monitor its systems. Over time, they steal data and compromise critical infrastructure. These attacks are particularly dangerous because they are difficult to detect and can remain unnoticed for months, allowing hackers to extract valuable information before the bank becomes aware of the breach.
sections.body6: Banks depend on third-party vendors and suppliers for various services, such as cloud storage and payment processing. Unfortunately, these third-party providers can be a weak link in a bank's cybersecurity chain. A cyberattack on a third-party vendor can create a backdoor, allowing hackers to access the bank's sensitive data.
sections.body7: Compliance violations can result in fines and other penalties. It is crucial to ensure that your organization and digitalization projects adhere to all applicable regulations.

sections.title: What is Risk Management?
sections.list: This encompasses the processes involved in planning, identifying, analyzing, responding to, and monitoring and controlling risks within a project.; The objectives are to enhance the likelihood and impact of positive events while reducing the probability and impact of adverse events affecting the project

sections.title: Risk Management Process
sections.body: The risk management process is comprised of four phases, as depicted in the following diagram: Identification, Assessment, Handling, and Monitoring
sections.body1: Risk identification involves examining project areas and critical technical processes to identify and document associated risks. Identifying potential issues, hazards, threats, and vulnerabilities that could negatively impact work efforts or plans forms the foundation of the risk management strategy. The project will employ several methods to identify risks:
sections.list1: Examination  the work breakdown structure to identify potential risk areas.; Conduct interviews with subject matter experts.; Analyze lessons learned documents or engage in discussions.; Examine design specifications for product enhancements, interfaces, and reports.; Evaluate project management and implementation strategies.; Perform risk assessment and risk management reviews.
sections.body2: Risk assessment involves analyzing identified risks and prioritizing them based on their potential threat to achieving project goals. During this phase, the project team examines each risk to determine its cause and potential effects. Risks are then rated based on their likelihood of occurrence and the severity of their impact on cost (e.g., Philippine Peso), schedule (e.g., time), and technical performance, as applicable.
sections.body3: Risk handling involves identifying, evaluating, selecting, and implementing options to manage risks at acceptable levels, considering project constraints and objectives. This process outlines specific actions to be taken, timelines, responsible parties, and associated costs and schedules. The handling strategy is determined based on the overall risk assessment rating, as detailed below.
sections.body4: Risk monitoring systematically tracks and evaluates the performance of risk-handling actions against established metrics throughout the project. It also involves developing additional risk-handling options as needed. To effectively control and manage risks during the project, the team regularly monitors both the risks and the outcomes of the risk-handling actions.; A Risk Register has been created to track each risk-handling activity for this project. Additionally, information on high overall risks will be included in the Monthly Project Status Report and discussed during Steering Committee meetings.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.body1: A risk is defined as a potential future threat to the overall success of a project or any of its components. Each risk is associated with a likelihood and a corresponding severity rating.
sections.body2: Any factors that you assume will be in place and contribute to the successful outcome of your project. An assumption is a statement accepted as fact. Assumptions must be validated.
sections.body3: An issue is an immediate, formally defined concern that requires action. It hinders the progress of a Workstream or the Program and lacks an agreed-upon resolution.
sections.body4: Dependencies are relationships between products or tasks. For instance, one product may consist of several other dependent products, or a task may not commence until a dependent task is completed.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.body: Utilizing a RAID log, or a similar tool, assists the PMO or Project Manager in capturing, organizing, prioritizing, and documenting the risks, assumptions, issues, and dependencies encountered during project planning and execution.
sections.body2: Phrases like It won’t work are not detailed enough. Ensure each entry is fully identified, explained, and well-documented with supporting references.
sections.body4: Regularly review risks and issues to determine if circumstances have changed.
sections.body5: Regularly validate assumptions and dependencies. As the project progresses, these may no longer be valid as originally stated.
sections.body6: Focus on high-impact and high-probability risks and issues. Each item should have clearly defined owners and expected next actions.
sections.body7: When necessary, review items for potential escalation using an escalation protocol managed by the PMO and governance processes.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.list1: A risk register is a document used as a risk management tool to identify potential setbacks within a project. The purpose of this process is to collectively identify, analyze, and address risks before they become problems.
sections.list2: According to the PMBOK guide, a risk register, or risk log, is a document that contains the results of risk analysis and records risk response plans. The primary output from risk identification is the initial entry into the risk register.
sections.list3: The risk register details all identified risks, provides descriptions, categorizes them, and discusses potential causes and probabilities. It also includes potential responses and identifies who is responsible for managing each risk. The risk register is an integral part of the project management plan.

sections.title: Risk Identification

sections.body2: After the identification is complete, a brief description should be added to your log.; A risk description should include:
sections.list2: A short, high-level overview of the risk; Why the risk is a potential issue; How long you choose to make your descriptions is up to how detailed you want your log to be, but the average length is typically 80 to 100 characters.; The main takeaway is that a description should accurately describe the risk without getting in the weeds so it can be easily identified.
sections.body3: Quickly identifying the risk facilitates assigning it to the appropriate team, especially when working on a complex project with multiple risks. A risk category could include any of the following:; To determine the category type, you first need to evaluate the source of the risk and identify who can help resolve it. If the solution isn't immediately clear, you may need to collaborate with department heads.
sections.list3: Operations; Budget; Schedule; Technology; Information; Security; Quality; Project plan
sections.body4: The estimated probability of the risk occurring.; The likelihood of a risk can be documented with a simple selection of: ; Categorizing your risks by likelihood helps prioritize which risks to address first and which can be deferred.
sections.body5: A risk analysis assesses the potential impact a risk could have on your project, helping to quickly identify the most critical risks to address. This should not be confused with priority, which considers both the likelihood and the impact analysis.; While teams document risk levels differently, you can start with this simple five-point scale: ; If you're having difficulty determining the risk level, consider seeking a second opinion from a department head. This collaboration can help you accurately assess the potential impact.
sections.list5: Very low; Low; Medium; High; Very high
sections.body6: A mitigation plan, also known as a risk response plan, is one of the most crucial components of a risk register. The primary goal of a risk management plan is to identify and mitigate potential risks. Essentially, it serves as an action plan.; A risk mitigation plan should include:
sections.list6: A step-by-step solution on how to lessen the risk; A brief description of the intended outcome; How the plan will affect the impact
sections.body7: While the impact of a risk helps determine its priority, it's important to include this information in your log as well. Priority should consider both the likelihood of the risk and the risk analysis. These aspects together will clarify which risks are most likely to have harmful consequences on the project.; Priority can be documented by a simple number scale:
sections.body8: The individual responsible for managing the risk and implementing the prevention or contingency plans. Risk owners can include stakeholders, members of the project team, the project manager, and the project sponsor.
sections.body9: This helps convey whether a risk has been successfully mitigated or not.; A risk status field should be filled out with one of the following: ; If you’d like to provide more detailed status options, you may choose a more specific list such as active, not started, on hold, ongoing, and complete.

sections.title: Risk Assessment
sections.body: A Probability and Risk Matrix is a grid used to map the likelihood of each risk occurring and its impact on project objectives if it does occur. This matrix specifies combinations of probability and impact, allowing individual project risks to be categorized into priority groups. By using the probability and impact matrix, risks are classified as low, medium, or high based on two distinct factors: the overall probability of occurrence and the presumed impact if it occurs.
sections.body1: Impact is evaluated based on the extent of changes to the work plan (timing), cost, and quality if the risk materializes.
sections.body2: Probability measures the likelihood that the risk will materialize.

sections.title: Risk Handling
sections.subheader: Four potential strategies to deal with risk:
sections.body1: Risk avoidance is a strategy in which the project team takes action to eliminate a threat or shield the project from its impact. This often involves modifying the Project Management plan to completely remove the threat.; The Project Manager may also isolate the project objectives from the risk's impact or alter the objective at risk. Examples include extending the schedule, changing the strategy, or reducing the scope. The most extreme avoidance strategy is to shut down the project entirely. Some risks that emerge early in the project can be avoided by clarifying requirements, gathering information, improving communication, or acquiring expertise
sections.body2: Risk mitigation is a strategy in which the project team takes action to reduce the likelihood or impact of a risk. This involves lowering the probability and/or impact of an adverse risk to within acceptable threshold limits.; Taking early action to minimize the probability and/or impact of a risk occurring is often more effective than attempting to address the damage after the risk has materialized. Examples of mitigation actions include adopting less complex processes, conducting additional tests, or selecting a more reliable supplier.; Mitigation may also involve developing prototypes to reduce the risk of scaling up from a bench-scale model of a process or product. When it is not possible to reduce the probability, a mitigation response might focus on addressing the risk impact by targeting linkages that determine its severity. For instance, designing redundancy into a system can reduce the impact of a failure of the original component.
sections.body3: Risk transfer is a strategy in which the project team shifts the impact of a threat to a third party, along with the responsibility for managing the response. Transferring the risk does not eliminate it; it simply assigns the responsibility for its management to another party. This does not mean disowning the risk by passing it to a later project or another person without their knowledge or agreement. Risk transfer typically involves paying a risk premium to the party assuming the risk.; Transferring liability for risk is particularly effective in managing financial risk exposure. Transfer tools can vary widely and include, but are not limited to, insurance, performance bonds, warranties, and guarantees. Contracts or agreements can be used to transfer liability for specific risks to another party. For example, if a buyer has capabilities that the seller lacks, it may be prudent to contractually transfer some work and its associated risk back to the buyer. In many cases, a cost-plus contract may transfer the cost risk to the buyer, while a fixed-price contract may transfer the risk to the seller.
sections.body4: Risk acceptance is a strategy in which the project team decides to acknowledge the risk and take no action unless the risk materializes. This approach is chosen when it is not feasible or cost-effective to address a specific risk in any other manner.; This strategy signifies that the project team has either decided not to alter the Project Management plan to address the risk or is unable to identify any other suitable response strategy. Risk acceptance can be either passive or active. Passive acceptance involves no action other than documenting the strategy, allowing the project team to address risks as they occur and periodically review the threat to ensure it does not change significantly. The most common active acceptance strategy is to establish a contingency reserve, which includes allocating time, money, or resources to manage the risks.

sections.title: What is QA?
sections.list: Quality assurance in project management involves implementing a set of actions aimed at ensuring that the project’s final outcomes align with the expected requirements. It focuses on the processes that teams utilize to maintain standards and deliver quality results.; This can be regarded as an added layer to conduct Risk Monitoring in projects.

sections.title: What is QA?
sections.body: International Organization for Standardization (ISO); The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is an independent, non-governmental international organization that develops guidelines for wide range of products, services, and systems to ensure quality, safety, and efficiency. These standards are globally recognized and adopted by businesses, governments, and organizations to establish uniformity and compliance across various sectors.; ISO maintains a family of quality management standards collectively known as the ISO 9000.
sections.body2: Pushing the team too hard to meet requirements can result in lower profits, higher risks, employee attrition, errors, and extra rework. Therefore, the process of creating the product is just as important as the product itself.
sections.body3: Upon the product’s availability, ask yourself:
sections.list 3: Upon the product’s availability, ask yourself:; If there is variations, is it acceptable?; Is it ready for use, and does it satisfy stakeholder expectations?

sections.title: Quality Strategies
sections.list: A strategy focused on continuous improvement; Every employee in the company is accountable for maintaining quality; Defines ‘quality’ based on customer requirements
sections.subheader1: Sample Quality Initiatives for Continuous Improvement
sections.body2: Employs a method of eliminating waste and improving value.
sections.body3: The Six Sigma standard, introduced by Bill Smith of Motorola, allows only 3.4 defects per million units. This technique is well-suited for manufacturing environments with large-scale production.

sections.title: Benefits of QA in Project Management
sections.body: When a project manager adopts QA standards throughout the project, the team will gain a clear understanding of the requirements for quality, leading to increased efficiency.
sections.body1: Employing QA processes helps project teams focus on delivering high-quality, error-free outcomes, which can guarantee customer satisfaction upon the product or service's release.
sections.body2: Team members who understand the QA standards for each project stage feel motivated to reach the desired results, thereby boosting their confidence and team morale.
sections.body3: Through QA methods, project managers are able to direct their efforts towards the continuous enhancement of processes to ensure quality standards are maintained.

sections.title: Benefits of QA in Project Management
sections.subheader: Pitfalls that can be avoided with a proactive approach to QA
sections.body1: Assigning testing tasks to business resources who lack expertise can cause unproductive and inaccurate testing. QA staff must thoroughly evaluate new testing technology and gather all relevant quality and testing requirements before implementation.
sections.body2: The QA needs of small banks differ from those of large, global institutions. What is effective for one may be too costly for another. Do not fall into the trap of believing that automation can resolve every QA issue.
sections.body3: This risk assumes that organizations can postpone adding QA resources and delay involving QA early in a project. Planning should include considerations for contractual negotiations and the timing of onboarding third-party vendors.
sections.body4: It's essential to incorporate all QA management activities in any significant endeavor. These include:
sections.list4: Test planning and obtaining approvals; Writing test cases; Executing tests; Fixing defects
sections.body5: QA executives should not assume that all testing resources share the same skill set. They must also understand the specific talents needed in frontline QA managers, such as whether the focus should be on process expertise or testing skills.
sections.body6: QA teams should incorporate the subject matter expertise provided by business users and not overlook their valuable insights. Additionally, QA leaders should avoid making decisions independently; instead, they should seek consensus and secure the support of these users.
sections.body7: Over-testing can lead to inflated costs and wasted time. The key criterion for testing is the value that the initiative delivers.

sections.title: Importance of QA in Digital Transformation Projects
sections.body: Form a trusted team comprising essential roles such as project management, technical leads, business leads, and business analysts.
sections.body1: Hire a QA lead or manager, either from within the bank or externally, selecting the most suitable candidate for the role.
sections.body2: Evaluate the qualifications required for your bank's QA team.
sections.body3: Consider existing staffs (business analysts and technical experts), but refrain from depending on them to serve as QA-trained resources.
sections.body4: Determine the size of effort that QA practice will address.
sections.body5: Assess the tools required for your QA practice.
sections.body6: Identify the training demands of the QA practice.
sections.body7: Consider the QA process and methodology crucial for your organization’s success.
sections.body8: Consider necessary communications for your organization.

sections.title: Importance of QA in Digital Transformation Projects
sections.body1: The rapid advancement of API technology, which often involves real-time integration, requires strong QA management to conduct thorough end-to-end testing whenever changes occur in your bank’s technology ecosystem. A strong QA practice provides the necessary oversight and discipline to ensure that newly combined solutions are adequately tested.
sections.body2: All software releases carry the risk of downtime. Prior to these scheduled events, it is essential for you and your stakeholders to assess the potential impact of a given release on revenue and production stability. Your assessment should be based on accurate QA data.

sections.title: Importance of QA in Digital Transformation Projects
sections.body: To establish a quality methodology, one should leverage established quality industry standards such as ISO 9001 – Quality Management System Requirements. These standards are ideal for setting up a best-practice quality management methodology within a bank. They require the institution to establish quality controls throughout its business processes to ensure customer requirements are fulfilled before delivering products and services.; In a proven QA methodology, management-level quality controls are commonly grouped into four phases: Plan, Do, Check, and Act.
sections.list 1: Determine the customer's expectations and requirements.; Identify and document the processes and quality controls needed to satisfy customer’s expectations.
sections.body2: Perform the established processes and quality controls—Prevent, Detect, and Correct—to ensure the customer's expectations are fulfilled: ; The product or service is handed over to the customer.
sections.list 2: Prevent – The processes and quality controls are implemented to avert the occurrence of defects.; Detect – The processes and quality controls are implemented to proactively identify possible defects.; Correct – The processes and quality controls are implemented to fix and resolve identified defects.
sections.list 3: Customer feedback is obtained.; Assess the effectiveness of the processes and quality controls by asking the question, Are the customer's expectations being met?

sections.title: Bangko Sentral framework for IT risk supervision
sections.list: ITRM should be considered a component and integrated with the institutions’ risk management program.; The guidelines likewise provide practical plans to address risks associated with emerging trends in technology and growing concerns on cyber security.
sections.list1: BSFIs employ advances in technology to sharpen business insights, enhance operational efficiencies, and deliver innovative financial products and services in line with emerging market trends and evolving client needs.; Technological developments also enable greater access to financial services that promote an inclusive and responsive digital financial ecosystem.; Social media platforms may further complicate matters as news of disruptions as well as customer complaints can spread at unprecedented speeds.; Cyber-threats and attacks confronting the financial services industry pose added risks that can undermine public trust and confidence in the financial system.; BSFIs should establish robust and effective technology risk management processes, governance structures, and cybersecurity controls to ensure that the benefits derived from technological innovations can be fully optimized without compromising financial stability, operational resilience, and consumer protection.
sections.list 2: The enhanced guidelines aim to provide guidance in managing risks associated with use of technology.; The guidelines are based on international standards and recognized principles of international practice for ITRM and shall serve as Bangko Sentral’s baseline requirement for all BSFIs.; The framework covers different facets of ITRM, some of which are supplemented with detailed guidelines in Appendices 74, 75, 76, 77, 78 and 79.; Subject guidelines, including the Appendices 74, 75, 76, 77, 78 and 79, are not “one-size-fits-all” and implementation of these need to be risk-based and commensurate with size, nature and types of products and services and complexity of IT operations of the individual BSFIs.; BSFIs shall exercise sound judgment in determining applicable provisions relevant to their risk profile.

sections.title: Bangko Sentral framework for IT risk supervision
sections.body: Appendices: IT Risk Management Standards and Guidelines
sections.body1: “…audit program should address IT risk exposures throughout the organization, including the areas of IT management and strategic planning, IT operations, client/server architecture, local and wide-area networks, telecommunications, physical and information security, electronic products and services, systems development and acquisition, and business continuity planning”
sections.body2: “…enables BSFIs to remain competitive and relevant as the financial services industry moves towards digital innovation.”
sections.subheader3: 76 Project Management/Development, Acquisition and Change  Management
sections.body3: “…enterprise-wide and ongoing approach should be formalized in the IT strategic plan to help ensure that all major IT projects are consistent with its overall strategic goals.”
sections.body4: “…necessitates the adoption of risk management processes that promote sound and controlled operation of IT environments to ensure that IT operations process and store information in a timely, reliable, secure, and resilient manner.”
sections.body5: “…risks may be realized in a different manner than if the functions were inside resulting in the need for well-structured process to properly manage risks and ensure that the interest of customers will not be compromised.”
sections.subheader6: 79 Electronic Banking, Electronic Payment, Electronic Money and Other Electronic Products and Services
sections.body6: “…the rapid development of electronic capabilities carries risks as well as benefits and it is important that these risks are recognized and managed by BSFIs in a prudent manner to promote safe and secure e-services and operations.”

sections.title: Bangko Sentral framework for IT risk supervision
sections.body: BSFIs are required to establish a robust ITRM system covering four key components:
sections.list1: Oversight and organization of IT functions; IT policies, procedures and standards; IT audit; Staff competence and training; Management Information Systems (MIS); IT risk management function
sections.list2: Begins with the identification of the current and prospective IT risk exposures arising from the institution’s IT environment and related processes.; Once management understands the institution’s IT environment and analyzes the risk, it should rank the risks and prioritize its response.; Periodic risk assessment process should be done at the enterprise-wide level and an effective monitoring program for the risk mitigation activities should be manifested through mitigation or corrective action plans, assignment of responsibilities and accountability and management reporting.
sections.list3: BSFI Management should implement satisfactory control practices that address the following as part of its overall IT risk mitigation strategy:; Information security; Project management/development and acquisition and change management; IT operations; IT outsourcing/Vendor management; Electronic banking, Electronic payments, Electronic money and other Electronic products and services
sections.list4: Performance vis-à-vis approved IT strategic plan; Performance benchmarks/service levels; Quality assurance/quality control; Policy compliance; External assessment program

sections.title: AFASA on Risk Management Systems and Controls to Protect Financial Accounts
sections.subheader: Anti-Financial Scamming Act (AFASA) was signed on July 20, 2024, and took effect on August 13, 2024
sections.subheader1: Section 6. Responsibility to Protect Access to Client’s Financial Account
sections.list: Institutions shall ensure that access to clients’ financial accounts is protected by adequate risk management systems and controls; Risk management systems and controls must be proportionate and commensurate to the nature, size and complexity of operations.; Institutions determined by the BSP to be compliant with the requirements of adequate risk management systems and controls shall not be liable for any loss or damage arising from the offenses under Sections 4 (Prohibited Acts) and Section 5 (Other Offenses).; Without prejudice to other liabilities under existing laws and consistent with BSP rules and regulations, institutions shall be liable for restitution of funds to the Account Owners for failure to employ adequate risk management systems and controls, or failure to exercise the highest degree of diligence in preventing loss or damage arising from the offenses under Section 4 and 5.; Conviction shall not be a prerequisite to the restitution of funds.
sections.body2: The following acts shall constitute Financial Account scamming under this Act:; (a) Money Muling Activities. A person performing any of the followings acts for the purpose of obtaining, receiving, depositing, transferring, or withdrawing proceeds that are known to be derived from crimes, offenses, or social engineering schemes shall be considered as a money mule:; (b) Social Engineering Schemes. A social engineering scheme is committed by a person who obtains sensitive identifying information of another person, through deception or fraud, resulting in unauthorized access and control over the person's Financial Account, by performing any of the following acts:; c) Economic Sabotage. The prohibited acts under Section 4(a) and (b) shall be considered as economic sabotage when committed under any of the following circumstances:
sections.list2: Using, borrowing or allowing the use of a Financial Account; Opening a Financial Account under a fictitious name or using the identity or identification documents of another; Buying or renting a Financial Account; Selling or lending a Financial Account; or Recruiting, enlisting, contracting, hiring, utilizing, or inducing any person to perform the acts mentioned in items 1 to 4 of this subsection.; Misrepresenting oneself as acting on behalf of an Institution, or making false representations to solicit another person's sensitive identifying information; or Using electronic communications to obtain another person's sensitive identifying information.; By a group of three (3) or more persons conspiring or confederating with one another; Against three (3) or more persons individually or as a group;Using a mass mailer; or Through human trafficking.
sections.body3: The following shall also constitute as offenses under this Act:
sections.list3: Willfully aiding or abetting in the commission of any of the offenses enumerated under Section 4; Willfully attempting to commit any of the offenses enumerated under Section 4; Opening a Financial Account under a fictitious name or using the identity or identification documents of another; or Buying or selling a Financial Account.
sections.subheader4: BSFIs should ensure adoption of the following key controls to protect financial accounts:
sections.list4: Fraud Management Systems (FMS); Infrastructure and security monitoring; Multi-factor Authentication (MFA); Account owner enrollment and verification processes, and ongoing monitoring of customer account and transactions; Audit Trail; Cybersecurity tests and evaluations
sections.body4: BSFIs which are determined compliant by the BSP shall not be liable for any loss or damage arising from the offenses under Section 4 and 5 of AFASA. However, BSFIs shall be liable for the restitution of funds to Account Owners for the failure to employ adequate risk management systems and controls for failure to exercise the highest degree of diligence in preventing loss or damage arising from the said offenses.

sections.title: Financial Services Cyber Resilience Plan 2024-2029
sections.body: This covers strategies to sharpen the industry’s capabilities to proactively respond to and recover from major cyber incidents.; Priority actions under this goal are:
sections.list: D1: Establish baseline industry incident response plan; D2: Develop scenario-based incident response playbooks; D3: Conduct progressive industry-wide cyber testing exercise regime; D4: Explore setting up of an industry Security Operations Center (SOC)
sections.body1: This encompasses strategies to institutionalize and expand sharing of timely and actionable cyberthreat intelligence across the financial community, including coordination and collaboration with other industry stakeholders and the National CERT (CERT-PH).; Priority actions under this goal are:
sections.list1: A1: Expand and further enhance Bankers Association of the Philippines Cybersecurity Incident Database (BAPCID) as an industry sharing platform; A2: Strengthen and forge strategic partnerships in domestic and international for a; A3: Support the enactment of cyber-related legislative initiatives (e.g., Anti-Financial Account Scamming Act, Liberalization of Secrecy of Deposits, etc.)
sections.body2: This goal covers strategies to instill strong cybersecurity culture and enhance cybersecurity skills and capabilities in the financial services industry.; Key priority actions include:
sections.list2: S1: Develop and implement cyber education program for BSFI Board and Senior Management; S2: Regularly conduct Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)/cyber form and Annual Cybersecurity Summit; S3: Conduct cybersecurity roadshows for small and medium-sized financial institutions (FIs); S4: Pursue holistic programs on cybersecurity skills and talent development; S5: Mainstream cyber education and awareness programs for financial clients.
sections.body3: This goal contains strategies to promote cybersecurity best practices and standards across cybersecurity domains.; Priority actions under this goal are:
sections.list3: H1: Complete policy reforms on digital security controls, Application Programming Interface (API) security, Cybersecurity Maturity Model (CMM) framework, and supply chain risk management; H2: Explore establishment of an Industry Cyber Innovation/Research Hub; H3: Conduct benchmarking exercises on cyber capabilities
